subject: Ethics
title: Brain Organoids and Consciousness
description: A quick, practical guide to Brain Organoids and Consciousness.

hook.text: Scientists are growing mini-brains in labs. Some produce electrical activity resembling a preterm infant's.

buildup.text: Brain organoids are tiny clusters of neurons grown from stem cells to study brain development and disease.

discovery.text: They've helped researchers understand Zika, Alzheimer's, and autism without experimenting on humans.

twist.text: As organoids grow more complex, a terrifying question emerges: could they develop consciousness or feel pain?

climax.text: No legal framework exists for when a lab-grown brain deserves moral consideration. We're flying blind.

punchline.text: If a brain in a dish can suffer, ignoring it is the real experiment.

quiz.question: What ethical question do increasingly complex brain organoids raise?
options: Whether brain organoids are too expensive for research
Whether they can be used to clone entire humans
Whether they could develop consciousness or the capacity to suffer
